Stars on Broadway

A spectre is haunting Broadway. Bringing huge status and gargantuan salaries, but sometimes poor performances, it is easy to see the inclusion of film stars and veteran actors in Broadway and West End shows as merely a populist move

Growing Pains: An Interview with The Pains of Being Pure at Heart

The Pains of Being Pure at Heart tell Adam Bychawski about their new album <em>Belong</em>

Occult Following

Songwriter Daniel Johnston talks to James Dixon

Future Sounds: Thundercat

As careers go, LA native Stephen Bruner has had a more varied one than most: he's been a touring session musician for Snoop Dogg and Eric Benet, had a stint in boy band No Curfew (apparently a hit in Germany), and played with hardcore legends Suicidal Tendencies (technically he still is a member) (Thumbnail credit Thundercat)

Hotly Tipped

<em>Nouse</em> Music recommend what to see at this year's music festivals. (Thumbnail credit Beyonce, John Cale, OFWGKTA, The Horrors, Pulp, Prince, Napalm Death, Richard Cheese, Dan Le Sac)

Castles In The Sky

Emily Heggadon looks at the arts scene in festivals (Thumbnail credit Jellyfish sculptures at Glastonbury)

Festival Playlist

A festival themed playlist compiled by the <em>Nouse</em> Music team

Blockbuster Season

From the final Harry Potter to a new Planet of the Apes movie, Michael Allard previews the big films of the summer (Thumbnail credit Above: Daniel Craig in &lt;em&gt;Cowboys and Aliens&lt;/em&gt;)

Top 5 Banned Movies

By James Bithell

<em>The Human Centipede II</em> isn't the first movie to feel the wrath of the BBFC - here are five classics that were once on the UK banned list

The Human Centipede II

This month the BBFC refused to certify a film for commercial release in the UK. Adrian Choa looks at what the fuss is all about

Green Lantern

<em>Green Lantern</em> is one of those films that gets everything right apart from acting and plot. It's a terrible movie, shrouded in great cinematography, spellbinding visual effects and a gloriously dramatic score

Senna

To refer to Asif Kapadia as the director of <em>Senna</em> is in many ways misleading. Leaving behind him a wealth of archive footage Senna can be said to have narrated his own life, and so Kapadia has not had to shoot a single frame of this movie

Tropical tasting

Emily Prideaux tries out some not-so-normal smoothie flavours

Indochine

Yorkshire, oriental and tapas are not three words that go comfortably together. With the Yorkshire stereotype tending towards a mean old man with a whippet, a flat cap, and questionable dentistry, my first thought was of miniscule portions

Pesto Chicken

This baked dish is simple and colourful. It uses 'mini fillet breasts' but you can use normal sized ones and cut them into 2 inch goujons

Summer Spirit

By James Bithell

Happy Birthday luxury fashion brand Gucci who celebrate their 90th year as one of the best in the business. The look is retro chic plus uber bold colours. Creative Director Frida Giannini is implementing a new eco-friendly strategy to project the brand into the future (Thumbnail credit Photos: style.com)

Trends: Royal Ascot

Stephen Jones, Ascot's official milliner for 2011, has made an impact with his feathered orange and purple hat adorned with poppies, worn not by a lady but a filly (to non-equine followers that's a female horse)

The Jackson Aftershock

As the second anniversary of Michael Jackson's death approaches the sense of loss certainly does not seem to have lessened. There are stars, there are superstars and there are legends. Jackson was all of these and more

Last orders

It's very difficult, writing a final column. The end of term is an emotional time for everyone and the temptation to make like Gwyneth Paltrow and start snotting, weeping and generally swooning all over my mac seems all too easy

Playboy by numbers

Playboy by numbers

Camilla Jenkins investigates: The daily grind

A very wise man (the Chief in Grey's Anatomy - where I get all my top tips) explained to success-thirsty young interns that life was a marathon and, at the end of it, you don't care if you win or lose, you'll just be glad you survived

MUSEings: taking it too far

"There is a line, ok, and I won't cross it!" These self-assured words were uttered from the wise mouth of Ollie (of <em>Made in Chelsea</em> fame) to Binky (likewise) as he stood in a cold open park wearing a gold thong, holding bananas in front of his crotch

Band of the Week: Cocteau Twins

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Treasure Island

PantSoc's 2011 summer pantomime has a big, energetic cast and genuinely entertaining moments, which make you really want to discount the rather freewheeling storyline and the one-too-many deliberately groan inducing puns

Red Snow

The discordant and the beautiful set the stage at the Barn this week with James Robert Ball's debut musical. Emily Heggadon urges you to see this piece of student written theatre of the highest calibre. Rating: ****

Review: Wet Nuns

With the pretentious decor of the Harley burning onto my retinas, the bobbing shield of heads is quite the blessing. Rating: ****

Band of the Week: The Gun Club

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Lady in lace?

It's the versatility of lace that makes it such an enduring fashion staple. But how do we update lace in summer 2011? Amy Cooke gives you a few ideas (Thumbnail credit Taylor Momsen makes lace more casual)

Road

Though to coin the production as merely "different" could be seen as ambiguous and degrading, it shows how <em>Road</em> is very much a breath of fresh air, and through its novelty promenade nature, has created a highly successful performance

Stars on Broadway

A spectre is haunting Broadway. Bringing huge status and gargantuan salaries, but sometimes poor performances, it is easy to see the inclusion of film stars and veteran actors in Broadway and West End shows as merely a populist move
